title: MLB DFS Plays: Tuesday 9/17
text:
This article will outline the best daily fantasy MLB plays of the day at every position. We’ll take a comprehensive look across the DFS industry to uncover these core recommendations, factoring respective salaries into the analysis.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

We will be looking at the 14-game main slate starting at 7:05 ET.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

PITCHER

Dallas Keuchel - Atlanta (vs. Philadelphia)

There are numerous cash game pitchers within this expanded 14-game slate, but Keuchel gets my vote with one of the best salary, floor, and ceiling combinations. His opponent, Philadelphia, ranks 19th in wRC+ (92) this season. Keuchel has found his groove lately with six straight quality starts, including a strong showing against the Phillies (6 IP, 3 H, 1 ER, 8 K, W) last Wednesday. A repeat performance isn’t out of the question.

Also Consider: Justin Verlander, Sonny Gray, Adam Plutko

CATCHER / FIRST BASE

Mitch Garver - Minnesota (vs. Chicago White Sox)

You read that correctly, as I’m seriously considering a catcher on sites where the backstop is merged with first basemen: that’s how good of a play Mitch Garver represents tonight. The Minnesota catcher is in the midst of an outstanding breakout season with a .279 average and 30 homers. Garver has been an absolute revelation against left-handed pitching, holding a 199 wRC+ and .417 ISO split in that regard. In other words, he carries outstanding upside against White Sox LHP Ross Detwiler’s .421 wOBA split to right-handed bats.

Also Consider: Freddie Freeman, Jose Abreu

Story continues

SECOND BASE

Robinson Cano - NY Mets (at Colorado)

The Mets represent the highest run-scoring projection of the night while taking their hacks in the hitting utopia of Coors Field. Colorado RHP Tim Melville has allowed 17 hits and 12 earned runs across 10.2 innings over his last three appearances, and I’m expecting that generosity to continue. Needless to say, Cano represents a strong lift within a promising Mets’ stack.

Also Consider: Ozzie Albies, Jurickson Profar

THIRD BASE

Vladimir Guerrero Jr. - Toronto (at Baltimore)

Guerrero holds a non-imposing salary with some exciting upside in his back pocket. That could be on full display against a horrible Baltimore pitching staff led by RHP Dylan Bundy’s .344 wOBA split to right-handed bats. Third base is extremely competitive tonight, but Vlad represents one of the better “per dollar” options on the board.

Also consider: Yoan Moncada, Miguel Sano

SHORTSTOP

Tim Anderson - Chicago White Sox (at Minnesota)

Minnesota LHP Martin Perez looked great through the first two months of the season, but it has been a rollercoaster ride ever since. The Twins’ southpaw owns a vulnerable .367 wOBA split to right-handed bats over the past two years, and the White Sox have several quality hitters to take advantage. That includes the impressive contact, power, and speed combination of Anderson, who is destined to make some fantasy noise in this draw.

Also Consider: Jonathan Villar, Xander Bogaerts

OUTFIELD

Jeff McNeil - NY Mets (at Colorado)

As mentioned earlier, the Mets represent the highest run-scoring projection of the night. I’ll definitely assemble NYM stacks against Colorado RHP Melville, especially in cash games. McNeil is one of my favorite hitters within that, fresh off a 2-5, HR, 2 RBI showing at Coors Field yesterday. McNeil, Cano, Michael Conforto, and Pete Alonso are the leading candidates within this well-aligned offense.

Nelson Cruz - Minnesota (vs. Chicago White Sox)

I’m all about stacking Mets and Twins while sprinkling in the other featured players to make a lineup work. Cruz and Garver represent my favorite lifts from Minnesota, as both demolish left-handed pitching. The 38-year-old designated hitter doesn’t seem phased by a wrist injury, clobbering massive homers with remarkable exit velocity over the past week. There should be more where that came from against White Sox LHP Detwiler’s vulnerabilities to right-handed bats.

Also consider: Michael Conforto, J.D. Martinez, Brandon Nimmo, J.D. Davis, Garrett Hampson, Eloy Jimenez, Matt Joyce (punt)
